##With the future in doubt, the Tokyo Olympics could be a big loss

I-CAIJING

CAIJING magazine official Wechat. "CAIJING" magazine, sponsored by the China Securities Market Research Center, was first published in 1998, adhering to the news concept of "independence, exclusiveness and originality" , and is known for authoritative, impartial and professional reporting, it is a must-read publication for policy-makers, researchers and managers in the field of politics and economics.

The uncertainty over the new crown epidemic has left companies on the fence about marketing spending and sponsoring the Olympics. That uncertainty has spread outward from the economic heart of the Games, and this year's games in Tokyo are likely to come under rare commercial pressure

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
By Wang Xiaofeng, CAIJING correspondent

Editor | Hao Zhou

Tokyo is gearing up for this year's summer Olympics at a cost of more than $10bn, with world-renowned companies and media spending billions for sponsorship and broadcast rights. Athletes from all over the world have been training for the Olympics for years, and only months remain before they reach the pinnacle of their careers. However, the recent global outbreak of new pneumonia and the severity of the situation in Japan have heightened fears that the summer Olympics may not be held as scheduled. Even if it does manage to do so, its business prospects are grim and the prospect of a loss looms large.

As of March 3, new cases of coronavirus have been confirmed in 73 countries, bringing the total number of confirmed cases to more than 90,000. The gradual easing of the outbreak in China has coincided with an increase in confirmed cases in Japan, South Korea, Iran and Italy, as well as an increase in deaths in some countries. As of 9:00 on March 4, there were 1,000 confirmed cases of NCP and 12 deaths from NCP in Japan. Among them, 280 cases were confirmed by Japanese and Chinese tourists, 706 cases were confirmed by the "Diamond Princess" cruise ship, and 14 cases were confirmed by those who returned from Wuhan by charter plane.

In an effort to reassure the public, the International Olympic Committee issued a statement on March 3rd expressing its full commitment to the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. This commitment is based on the advice of the World Health Organization. A Joint Task Force on the outbreak was set up in mid February with members from the International Olympic Committee, the Tokyo Olympic Organizing Committee, the Japanese and Tokyo governments, and the World Health Organization Organization, the statement said.

The International Olympic Committee's announcement is good news for the Tokyo Olympics, which have come under intense pressure from the Tokyo Organizing Committee, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government and the Japanese government since the diamond princess intensified the outbreak in Japan and then escalated the global epidemic, high-level Japanese repeatedly stressed that the Olympic Games will be held as scheduled, still can not dispel the doubts of the outside world.

Postpone or cancel the final power in the Olympic Committee

Dick Pound, a senior member of the International Olympic Committee, told reporters that the Games could be canceled or postponed if the outbreak is not contained within the next three months. That statement set off a firestorm. As for the future of the Tokyo Games, Seiko Hashimoto, Japan's Olympics Minister, revealed at a meeting of the Senate Budget Committee on March 3rd that they could be extended by 2020 under the host city contract.

Although Seiko Hashimoto stressed that she would press ahead with the Games as scheduled, her words were interpreted as implying that the games might be delayed until the end of the year. Regarding this possibility, Zhang Qing, CEO of Beijing Key Way Sports Consulting Company, told CAIJING reporter that, "It is unlikely that an entire Olympics will be cancelled because of the enormous effort and cost involved by both the athletes, the organisers and the business community, " Hashimoto said.

Among Zhang's clients are Chinese Olympic Committee sponsors, who see the Games in Tokyo as a very important marketing opportunity. As usual, with the Olympics in July, marketing is about to begin, but nothing is happening now, as the uncertainty surrounding the new crown epidemic has left companies on the fence about marketing and sponsoring the Games. This uncertainty has spread from the Olympic economic arteries to capillary.

The Olympic Games are not only a global sporting event, but also a highly market-oriented global economic activity that involves all parties, so the decision to cancel is by no means an easy one. The uncertainty surrounding the outbreak has rattled capital markets, especially the insurance industry, which faces huge bills and billions of dollars in underwriting costs if the Tokyo Olympics are cancelled. Jefferies analysts estimate the cost of insuring the 2020 games at $2 billion, including television rights and sponsorships, plus $600 million in hospitality.

Because of this, the Olympics have never been canceled for anything other than war in history. If Tokyo holds the Games as scheduled in July, it will be the first Asian city in history to host two Summer Games. Tokyo hosted the first Olympic Games in 1964.

The ultimate authority to postpone or cancel the Games rests with the International Olympic Committee. Seiko Hashimoto believes the International Olympic Committee will decide by the end of May whether the Tokyo Olympics will be held as scheduled. Under the host city contract, signed by the International Olympic Committee and the Tokyo Metropolitan Government, the International Olympic Committee has the right to terminate the contract on its own if there are grounds to believe that the safety of Olympic participants will be seriously threatened.

The provision has led some Japanese to worry that the International Olympic Committee might, in some cases, put the idea of hosting a city behind it and make a unilateral decision. They believe that the future may depend to a large extent on what who thinks about the Olympics. Marion Koopmans, a senior WHO expert, told Caijing that the success of the Games depended on whether the new coronavirus was controlled through prevention and control measures in China and other countries and regions.

There could be a huge price tag

Cancelling the Olympic Games for non-war reasons is unprecedented, and in today's high economic globalization, the losses will also affect everything. "If the Olympics were cancelled, the economic losses would be multi-faceted, including the media rights that the International Olympic Committee would have received and the loss of TOP sponsors' revenues, as well as compensation. Sponsors and media don't get their money back, and they don't get their money back. If the organizing committee does not get the income, the investment of the city's facilities, infrastructure and city operation can not be recovered, it is all a loss. The BOCOG is expected to spend US $5.6 billion and the venue facilities US $7 billion, which is a loss,"Yi Jiandong, an Olympic expert and professor at Wenzhou University, told Caijing.

Although the International Olympic Committee can avoid liability to its hosts through texts such as Olympic Charter, Yi explained that the Media Rights International Olympic Committee earns and the TOP sponsors'revenues will be lost, there may be some liability for breach of contract. This has huge implications for the International Olympic Committee, whose main sources of revenue are media rights and TOP sponsorship, without which the promised fees to individual organisations and nocs would not exist.

In response to the risk, the International Olympic Committee set up a reserve fund as a risk management tool. The International Olympic Committee has also set up a $647m asset from television broadcasting revenues to pay back contracts as needed. An additional $261 million was used to cover losses on large-scale sponsorship projects and $447 million was distributed to National Olympic institutions. However, the safe haven coffers will not be able to recoup the financial costs of cancelling a single Olympics, especially the TOP sponsorship and television rights that the International Olympic Committee has to pay for.

According to the International Olympic Committee's 2013-2016 financial report, 73 percent of the agency's revenue comes from the sale of broadcast rights, 18 percent from TOP sponsors, 5 percent from other revenue and 4 percent from the sale of other contractual rights. Ninety per cent of the proceeds go to the Olympics and sports development, amounting to $5 billion. In addition to hosting the Olympics, the money will go to national / regional and international sports authorities to fund athletes around the world. At the Rio Games, for example, the International Olympic Committee gave $540m to international sports bodies and another $540m to National Olympic Committees.

Both television rights and sponsorship costs have risen sharply this year. Discovery Communications, the parent company of Eurosport, paid 1.3 billion euros ($1.4 billion) to broadcast the 2018-to-2024 games across Europe. Comcast, the parent company of NBC Universal, paid $4.38 billion for the rights to broadcast the four Olympics from 2014 to 2020.

Currently, International Olympic Committee has 14 TOP sponsors, including Alibaba, which has a contract with the IOC up to 2028, and media estimates put the total value of Alibaba's sponsorship at no less than $800 million. Samsung's contract with International Olympic Committee is also believed to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Cancelling the Games, along with television rights and TOP sponsorship, would be a lost cause for the International Olympic Committee.

Cancelling the Games will also have a direct impact on the revenues of the Tokyo Organizing Committee. It is reported that the amount of domestic sponsorship for the Tokyo Games has reached a record high of $3 billion, according to the International Olympic Committee, that's more than $3 billion in domestic sponsorship money, three times the amount spent on recent Olympics. The record domestic sponsorship revenue for the Games came from London in 2012, which raised about $1.1 billion from domestic sponsors.

Domestic sponsorship for the Tokyo Olympics is divided into three tiers, with 15 top gold partners, 32 official partners and 18 official suppliers having been signed, bringing the total to 65 sponsors. The top gold partners have to pay nine figures, or more than $100m. The 62 domestic sponsors do not include Bridgestone, Panasonic and Toyota, which have signed top global partnership agreements with International Olympic Committee worth hundreds of millions of dollars each.

Not only is the sponsorship record high, but Tokyo's Olympic budget is several times over what was originally envisaged. Last December, organizers of the Tokyo Olympics said they expected to spend about 1.35 trillion yen ($12.35 billion) , not including the 3 billion yen needed to move the marathon and walking events from Tokyo to Sapporo. The Tokyo Olympics budget is split between the organizing committee and local and national governments, with the International Olympic Committee contributing more than $800 million.

The cost will go up no matter what

The uncertainty surrounding the outbreak has led to widespread concerns that the cost of the Games in Tokyo could rise further, and that such a high budget, let alone a cancellation, or even a postponement, would put huge pressure on the Tokyo Organizing Committee. "If the Games are postponed, the cost of hosting the Games will increase, not only in terms of manpower and operation costs, but also in terms of epidemic prevention costs, " Zhang said.

Not only that, but the outbreak could also have an impact on the size of the Tokyo Olympics, because even if it does go ahead, it may have to limit the number of spectators and the scale of marketing in the run-up to the Games, both of which are economic losses. "The impact of controlling the number of spectators on the Tokyo Olympics will not only be a drop in ticket revenue, but also a drop in sponsorship revenue and an inefficient city operation, but the overall impact will not be too great, " Yi said.

Even some analysts are worried about whether the Tokyo Olympics will repeat the losses of the Montreal Games. Regarding the possibility, Yi Jiandong thinks it is unlikely to repeat because the Tokyo Olympics will not lose money, you can't just calculate the economic cost of the event (the organizing committee won't lose too much because ticket revenue isn't a big part of it) , but also the efficiency of the venues and infrastructure used after the event, including whether the city's operation will improve efficiency in the future.

The 1976 Games in Montreal lost $2.4 billion, leaving the city with years of debt, a total of $1 billion that was paid off 30 years later in November 2006, the biggest loss in the history of the modern games, it also kept many cities from bidding for the Games until the 1984 games in Los Angeles were in the black. The main reason for the losses is the huge cost of the stadiums and the difficulty of building the main stadium, which will not be completed until more than a decade after the Games, which cost Montreal $5.8 bn.

From historical experience, the loss of the Olympic Games is partly due to the fact that the venues after the Games can not be put to good use, because the cost of building stadiums is high, but it does not produce any economic benefits, and it is basically unable to attract investment, it will be paid for with public money, for example, the failing venues of the 2004 Olympics became a metaphor for Greece's economic crisis, while the Los Angeles Games were successful because planners avoided building new stadiums.

A total of 43 venues will open for the Tokyo Olympics, including eight new permanent venues, the new national arena is estimated to cost nearly 160 billion yen ($1.5 billion) , and the Tokyo Metropolitan Government has put post-games sustainable use on the agenda, but there are still questions about the size of the new National Stadium. How to deal with this problem will be the Tokyo Olympic Games can avoid one of the key losses.

In addition to the venues, Zhang Qing believes that whether the Olympics will be profitable depends on how it is defined. Although the cost is huge, the brand benefits that the Olympics will bring to cities and countries are also huge, and the promotion of urban public facilities will drive GDP growth, job Creation, these are gains in a broad sense.

With less than 150 days to go until the Games, sponsors are holding their breath as the athletes prepare for the games. "In view of the International Olympic Committee statement that the Olympics are likely to be held, enterprises should still make preparations early, Olympic resources are scarce and quadrennial events should still be grasped, " Zhang said.

Read more about the outbreak in pictures
